etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Abraham Fleming (c1552–1607), author, literary editor, and Church of England clergyman. From post-classical Latin persuasorius persuasive from classical Latin persuās-, past participial stem of persuādēre + -ōrius. Compare Middle French, French †persuasoire persuasive, convincing, Portuguese persuasório

definitions: persuasive; intended to persuade; relating to persuasion.
